title: Battle of Actium (31 BC)
desc: Naval battle between Octavian and Mark Antony & Cleopatra.
desc_long: The Battle of Actium, fought on 2 September 31 BC, was a decisive confrontation of the Final War of the Roman Republic. Octavian's victory led to the rise of the Roman Empire.

title: Bar Kokhba revolt (132–136)
desc: Jewish revolt against Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Bar Kokhba revolt was a major Jewish uprising against Roman rule in Judaea, resulting in massive casualties and the renaming of the province.

title: Gothic War (376–382)
desc: Conflict between Goths and Eastern Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Gothic War marked the beginning of large-scale Germanic migrations into Roman territory, culminating with the Battle of Adrianople.

title: Early Muslim conquests (7th century)
desc: Rapid Arab expansion across Middle East and North Africa.
desc_long: The early Muslim conquests transformed the political and cultural landscape of the Middle East, North Africa, and beyond, leading to the establishment of the Islamic Caliphate.

title: Byzantine–Sassanid War (602–628)
desc: Last great war of antiquity between Byzantium and Persia.
desc_long: The final and most devastating conflict between the Byzantine and Sassanid Empires, resulting in exhaustion of both and paving the way for Arab invasions.

title: Mongol invasion of Khwarezmia (1219–1221)
desc: Genghis Khan's campaign against Khwarezmian Empire.
desc_long: The Mongol invasion of Khwarezmia led to the destruction of cities and massive loss of life, showcasing Mongol military prowess and brutality.

title: Hundred Years' War (1337–1453)
desc: Long conflict between England and France.
desc_long: The Hundred Years' War was a series of conflicts waged for control of the French throne, marked by famous battles and the rise of Joan of Arc.

title: Greek War of Independence (1821–1830)
desc: Revolutionary war by Greek revolutionaries against the Ottoman Empire.
desc_long: The Greek War of Independence led to the establishment of an independent Greek state and inspired nationalist movements across Europe.

title: Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)
desc: Major conflict between the Russian and Ottoman Empires.
desc_long: The Russo-Turkish War led to the independence of several Balkan states and the decline of Ottoman influence in Europe.

title: American Revolutionary War (1775–1783)
desc: Colonial revolt against British rule.
desc_long: The American Revolution led to the independence of the United States and inspired movements worldwide.

title: Shaka's Zulu Wars (1816–1828)
desc: Expansion and consolidation of the Zulu Kingdom under Shaka.
desc_long: Shaka's military campaigns transformed southern Africa, leading to the Mfecane and significant social upheaval.

title: French Revolutionary Wars (1792–1802)
desc: Series of major conflicts after the French Revolution.
desc_long: The French Revolutionary Wars spread revolutionary ideals and led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte.

title: Anglo-Zulu War (1879)
desc: British Empire vs. Zulu Kingdom in South Africa.
desc_long: The Anglo-Zulu War saw dramatic victories and defeats, including the famous Battle of Isandlwana.

title: Boshin War (1868–1869)
desc: Japanese civil war between shogunate and imperial forces.
desc_long: The Boshin War led to the Meiji Restoration and the modernization of Japan.

title: First Opium War (1839–1842)
desc: Conflict between Britain and China over opium trade.
desc_long: The First Opium War led to the Treaty of Nanking and the opening of Chinese ports to foreign trade.

title: Second Opium War (1856–1860)
desc: Anglo-French alliance vs. Qing China.
desc_long: The Second Opium War further weakened the Qing dynasty and expanded Western influence in China.

title: Taiping Rebellion (1850–1864)
desc: Massive civil war in southern China.
desc_long: The Taiping Rebellion, led by Hong Xiuquan, was one of the deadliest conflicts in history, causing 20–30 million deaths.

title: Sengoku period (1467–1615)
desc: Era of civil war, social upheaval, and political intrigue in Japan.
desc_long: The Sengoku period saw the rise of powerful daimyōs and the eventual unification of Japan under the Tokugawa shogunate.

title: Punic Wars (264–146 BC)
desc: Series of three wars between Rome and Carthage.
desc_long: The Punic Wars were a series of conflicts that established Rome's dominance over the western Mediterranean, culminating in the destruction of Carthage.

title: The Crusades (1096–1291)
desc: Religious wars sanctioned by the Latin Church in the medieval period.
desc_long: The Crusades were a series of religious wars in the medieval period, primarily between Christians and Muslims for control of the Holy Land.

title: Wars of the Roses (1455–1487)
desc: Civil wars in England for control of the throne.
desc_long: The Wars of the Roses were a series of dynastic conflicts for the throne of England, fought between the houses of Lancaster and York.

title: Great Northern War (1700–1721)
desc: Conflict in Northern, Central, and Eastern Europe.
desc_long: The Great Northern War saw Russia's emergence as a great power after defeating Sweden.

title: Seven Years' War (1756–1763)
desc: Global conflict involving most great powers.
desc_long: The Seven Years' War is sometimes considered the first 'world war', fought in Europe, the Americas, West Africa, India, and the Philippines.

title: Mexican–American War (1846–1848)
desc: Conflict between United States and Mexico.
desc_long: The Mexican–American War resulted in significant territorial losses for Mexico and the expansion of the United States.

title: Crimean War (1853–1856)
desc: War fought in the Crimean Peninsula.
desc_long: The Crimean War involved Russia against an alliance of the Ottoman Empire, France, Britain, and Sardinia, and is remembered for the Charge of the Light Brigade.

title: Second Boer War (1899–1902)
desc: War between the British Empire and two Boer states.
desc_long: The Second Boer War marked the end of independent Boer republics and the beginning of British dominance in South Africa.

title: Russo-Japanese War (1904–1905)
desc: Conflict between Russia and Japan over imperial ambitions.
desc_long: The Russo-Japanese War resulted in a surprising victory for Japan and marked the first major military victory of an Asian power over a European power in modern times.

title: Balkan Wars (1912–1913)
desc: Series of conflicts in the Balkan Peninsula.
desc_long: The Balkan Wars led to the territorial contraction of the Ottoman Empire in Europe and set the stage for World War I.

title: Greco-Turkish War (1919–1922)
desc: War between Greece and Turkish National Movement.
desc_long: The Greco-Turkish War was fought in the aftermath of World War I and led to the population exchange between Greece and Turkey.

title: Chaco War (1932–1935)
desc: War between Bolivia and Paraguay.
desc_long: The Chaco War was the bloodiest military conflict of South America in the 20th century.

title: Korean War (1950–1953)
desc: War between North and South Korea involving UN and China.
desc_long: The Korean War was a conflict on the Korean Peninsula between North Korea (supported by China and the Soviet Union) and South Korea (supported by a UN coalition led by the USA).

title: Algerian War of Independence (1954–1962)
desc: War between France and the Algerian National Liberation Front.
desc_long: The Algerian War led to Algeria's independence from France and was marked by guerrilla warfare and atrocities on both sides.

title: Nigerian Civil War (1967–1970)
desc: Conflict between Nigeria and the secessionist state of Biafra.
desc_long: The Nigerian Civil War, also known as the Biafran War, resulted in massive civilian casualties due to famine and fighting.

title: Bangladesh Liberation War (1971)
desc: War of independence of Bangladesh from Pakistan.
desc_long: The Bangladesh Liberation War resulted in the creation of Bangladesh and is remembered for widespread atrocities and a major refugee crisis.

title: Yom Kippur War (1973)
desc: War between Israel and a coalition of Arab states.
desc_long: The Yom Kippur War was a surprise attack against Israel by Egypt and Syria, leading to a large-scale conflict in the Middle East.

title: Ethiopian–Eritrean War (1998–2000)
desc: Conflict between Ethiopia and Eritrea.
desc_long: The Ethiopian–Eritrean War was a border conflict that resulted in tens of thousands of deaths.

title: Second Congo War (1998–2003)
desc: Deadliest war in modern African history.
desc_long: The Second Congo War involved multiple African countries and caused millions of deaths, mostly from disease and starvation.

title: Darfur conflict (2003–ongoing)
desc: Ongoing conflict in the Darfur region of Sudan.
desc_long: The Darfur conflict has led to genocide allegations, massive displacement, and humanitarian crises.

title: Syrian Civil War (2011–present)
desc: Multi-sided armed conflict in Syria.
desc_long: The Syrian Civil War began as a protest movement and escalated into a complex international conflict involving numerous factions.

title: Libyan Civil War (2011–2020)
desc: Series of conflicts in Libya after the fall of Gaddafi.
desc_long: The Libyan Civil War involved various factions vying for control after the ousting of Muammar Gaddafi.

title: Antonine Plague (165–180)
desc: A deadly plague, possibly smallpox, that affected the Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Antonine Plague, believed to be smallpox, killed up to 5 million people across the Roman Empire.

title: First Anglo-Afghan War (1839–1842)
desc: British invasion and retreat from Afghanistan.
desc_long: The First Anglo-Afghan War was a disastrous campaign for the British, ending with a near-total loss of the retreating army from Kabul.

title: Second Anglo-Afghan War (1878–1880)
desc: Second British campaign in Afghanistan.
desc_long: The Second Anglo-Afghan War reaffirmed British influence in Afghanistan, though the country remained officially independent.

title: Second Italo-Ethiopian War (1935–1936)
desc: Fascist Italy's invasion of Ethiopia.
desc_long: The Second Italo-Ethiopian War resulted in the occupation of Ethiopia and was a precursor to World War II.

title: Iran–Iraq War (1980–1988)
desc: Prolonged and devastating conflict between Iran and Iraq.
desc_long: The Iran–Iraq War was one of the longest and bloodiest conflicts of the 20th century, resulting in enormous casualties and economic damage.

title: Gulf War (1990–1991)
desc: U.S.-led coalition expelled Iraqi forces from Kuwait.
desc_long: The Gulf War featured a massive coalition force led by the U.S. to liberate Kuwait from Iraqi occupation.

title: Kargil War (1999)
desc: Armed conflict between India and Pakistan in the Kargil district.
desc_long: The Kargil War was fought in the mountains of Kashmir and involved high-altitude combat and international diplomatic pressure.

title: Falklands War (1982)
desc: Conflict between the UK and Argentina over the Falkland Islands.
desc_long: The Falklands War resulted in British victory and the islands remaining under UK control.

title: Ogaden War (1977–1978)
desc: War between Ethiopia and Somalia over the Ogaden region.
desc_long: The Ogaden War saw shifting Cold War alliances and a decisive Ethiopian victory.

title: Six-Day War (1967)
desc: Brief but pivotal Arab–Israeli war.
desc_long: The Six-Day War resulted in Israel capturing the Sinai Peninsula, Golan Heights, Gaza Strip, and West Bank.

title: First Indochina War (1946–1954)
desc: War between French Union and Viet Minh.
desc_long: The First Indochina War ended with the defeat of France at Dien Bien Phu and the partition of Vietnam.

title: Cambodian Civil War (1967–1975)
desc: Conflict between Khmer Rouge and Cambodian government.
desc_long: The Cambodian Civil War resulted in the rise of the Khmer Rouge and the Cambodian genocide.

title: Rwandan Genocide and Civil War (1994)
desc: Mass killings and civil war in Rwanda.
desc_long: The Rwandan Civil War and genocide led to the deaths of up to a million people, mostly Tutsi.

title: Bosnian War (1992–1995)
desc: Part of the Yugoslav Wars after breakup of Yugoslavia.
desc_long: The Bosnian War involved ethnic cleansing and was ended by the Dayton Agreement.

title: Kosovo War (1998–1999)
desc: Conflict in Kosovo and NATO bombing of Yugoslavia.
desc_long: The Kosovo War ended with NATO intervention and the withdrawal of Yugoslav forces.

title: Chechen Wars (1994–2009)
desc: Conflicts between Russian Federation and Chechen Republic.
desc_long: The First and Second Chechen Wars saw intense fighting, terrorist attacks, and massive destruction in Chechnya.

title: Russian invasion of Ukraine (2022–2026, ongoing)
desc: Full-scale invasion launched by Russia.
desc_long: The ongoing war marks a major European conflict, with widespread destruction, humanitarian crisis, and global impact.

title: Second Sudanese Civil War (1983–2005)
desc: Conflict between the central Sudanese government and the Sudan People's Liberation Army.
desc_long: The Second Sudanese Civil War led to the independence of South Sudan and was one of the longest and deadliest wars in Africa.

title: Mexican Drug War (2006–2026, ongoing)
desc: Ongoing conflict between Mexican government and drug cartels.
desc_long: The Mexican Drug War has resulted in hundreds of thousands of deaths and has had a significant impact on security in Mexico.

title: Israeli–Palestinian conflict (1948–2026, ongoing)
desc: Long-running conflict between Israel and Palestinian groups.
desc_long: The Israeli–Palestinian conflict spans decades, with multiple wars, uprisings, and peace attempts.

title: Tigray War (2020–2022)
desc: Conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray Region.
desc_long: The Tigray War involved the Ethiopian government, regional forces, and Eritrea, resulting in a humanitarian catastrophe.

title: Nagorno-Karabakh War (2020)
desc: War between Azerbaijan and Armenia-backed forces.
desc_long: The 2020 war in Nagorno-Karabakh resulted in significant territorial changes and casualties.

title: Sahel conflict (2012–2026, ongoing)
desc: Ongoing armed conflict in the Sahel region of West Africa.
desc_long: The Sahel conflict involves jihadist groups, state militaries, and international forces across Mali, Niger, Burkina Faso, and neighboring countries.

title: Gunpowder Plot (1605)
desc: Failed attempt to blow up the English Parliament.
desc_long: On 5 November 1605, a group of English Catholics led by Guy Fawkes attempted to assassinate King James I and blow up the House of Lords. The plot was foiled, and the event is commemorated in the UK as Guy Fawkes Night.

title: Cawnpore Massacre (1857)
desc: Massacre of British civilians during Indian Rebellion.
desc_long: In June 1857, during the Indian Rebellion, hundreds of British civilians were massacred at Cawnpore after promises of safe passage were broken.

title: Haymarket affair (1886)
desc: Bombing at a labor rally in Chicago.
desc_long: A bomb thrown at police during a labor rally in Chicago killed seven police officers and several civilians, sparking a nationwide crackdown on labor activists.

title: Wall Street bombing (1920)
desc: Deadly bombing in New York's financial district.
desc_long: On September 16, 1920, a horse-drawn wagon filled with explosives detonated on Wall Street, killing 38 and injuring hundreds. The perpetrators were never caught.

title: King David Hotel bombing (1946)
desc: Bombing by Zionist militants against British authorities.
desc_long: On 22 July 1946, members of the Irgun bombed the King David Hotel in Jerusalem, killing 91 people. It was one of the deadliest attacks during the British Mandate of Palestine.

title: Milk Bar Café bombing (1956)
desc: FLN bombing in Algiers during Algerian War.
desc_long: On 30 September 1956, a bomb placed by Algerian nationalists exploded in the Milk Bar Café in Algiers, part of a wave of urban terrorism during the Algerian War of Independence.

title: Bologna massacre (1980)
desc: Terrorist bombing at Bologna railway station.
desc_long: On 2 August 1980, a bomb exploded at the Bologna Centrale railway station in Italy, killing 85 people and wounding over 200 in the deadliest attack in Italian history.

title: 1993 Bombay bombings
desc: Series of 12 bomb explosions across Mumbai.
desc_long: On 12 March 1993, a series of 12 coordinated bomb explosions took place in Mumbai, India, killing 257 and injuring over 1,400.

title: Oklahoma City bombing (1995)
desc: Truck bombing of federal building in Oklahoma.
desc_long: On April 19, 1995, Timothy McVeigh detonated a truck bomb at the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building, killing 168 and injuring hundreds.

title: Markale market shelling (1994)
desc: Shelling of civilian market in Sarajevo.
desc_long: On 5 February 1994, a mortar shell killed 68 and wounded 144 in Sarajevo during the Bosnian War, in one of the bloodiest single attacks of the siege.

title: 1998 United States embassy bombings
desc: Coordinated truck bomb attacks on US embassies in Kenya and Tanzania.
desc_long: On 7 August 1998, Al-Qaeda bombed the US embassies in Nairobi and Dar es Salaam, killing 224 people and injuring thousands.

title: 2003 Casablanca bombings
desc: Series of suicide bombings in Casablanca.
desc_long: On 16 May 2003, a series of suicide bombings killed 45 people in Casablanca, Morocco.

title: 2004 Madrid train bombings
desc: Coordinated bombings of commuter trains.
desc_long: On 11 March 2004, ten bombs exploded on four trains in Madrid, killing 193 people and injuring around 2,000.

title: Beslan school siege (2004)
desc: Hostage crisis in Beslan, North Ossetia.
desc_long: From 1–3 September 2004, over 1,100 people were taken hostage at School No. 1 in Beslan. The siege ended with more than 330 deaths.

title: Sharm El Sheikh bombings (2005)
desc: Bombings at Egyptian resort city.
desc_long: On 23 July 2005, a series of bomb attacks killed 88 people and wounded over 150 in Sharm El Sheikh.

title: Algiers bombings (2007)
desc: Al-Qaeda bombings of United Nations offices in Algiers.
desc_long: On 11 December 2007, two car bomb attacks killed 41 people and injured more than 170.

title: 2008 Mumbai attacks
desc: Coordinated shooting and bombing attacks in Mumbai.
desc_long: From 26–29 November 2008, a series of attacks killed 166 people and wounded over 300 in Mumbai.

title: Peshawar school massacre (2014)
desc: Taliban attack on Army Public School in Peshawar.
desc_long: On 16 December 2014, Taliban gunmen killed 149 people, including 132 children, in one of the deadliest terrorist attacks in Pakistan.

title: Bardo National Museum attack (2015)
desc: ISIS attack on museum in Tunis.
desc_long: On 18 March 2015, two gunmen killed 22 people at the Bardo National Museum in Tunis, Tunisia.

title: November 2015 Paris attacks
desc: Coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris.
desc_long: On 13 November 2015, a series of coordinated attacks in Paris killed 130 people and injured hundreds.

title: 2016 Brussels bombings
desc: Suicide bombings at Brussels airport and metro.
desc_long: On 22 March 2016, two suicide bombings at Brussels Airport and one at a metro station killed 32 people and wounded over 300.

title: Istanbul nightclub attack (2017)
desc: Gun attack at Reina nightclub on New Year's Day.
desc_long: On 1 January 2017, a gunman killed 39 people at the Reina nightclub in Istanbul.

title: Manchester Arena bombing (2017)
desc: Suicide bombing at Ariana Grande concert.
desc_long: On 22 May 2017, a suicide bomber killed 22 and injured over 800 at the Manchester Arena.

title: Christchurch mosque shootings (2019)
desc: Terrorist shootings at two mosques in Christchurch.
desc_long: On 15 March 2019, a gunman attacked two mosques in Christchurch, New Zealand, killing 51 people.

title: Kabylia bombings (2022)
desc: Series of bomb attacks in Algeria's Kabylia region.
desc_long: A series of coordinated bombings in 2022 in Kabylia, Algeria, that resulted in dozens of casualties.

title: Antonine Plague (165–180)
desc: A deadly plague, possibly smallpox, that affected the Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Antonine Plague, believed to be smallpox, killed up to 5 million people across the Roman Empire and weakened its military and economy.

title: Plague of Cyprian (249–262)
desc: A pandemic that devastated the Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Plague of Cyprian swept through the Roman Empire, causing widespread death and social disruption in the 3rd century.

title: Plague of Justinian (541–542)
desc: First recorded outbreak of bubonic plague.
desc_long: The Plague of Justinian was one of the deadliest pandemics, killing millions across the Mediterranean and disrupting the Byzantine Empire.

title: Black Death (1346–1353)
desc: Devastating global epidemic of bubonic plague.
desc_long: The Black Death killed up to 60% of Europe's population and tens of millions in Asia and Africa, reshaping societies and economies.

title: Cocoliztli Epidemics (1545–1576)
desc: Deadly epidemics that struck Mexico after Spanish contact.
desc_long: The Cocoliztli epidemics may have killed 5–15 million indigenous people in Mexico, devastating native civilizations.

title: Smallpox in the Americas (1520–1800)
desc: Smallpox devastated indigenous populations after European contact.
desc_long: Smallpox killed an estimated 56 million people in the Americas, wiping out up to 90% of native populations after European arrival.

title: Great Plague of London (1665–1666)
desc: Bubonic plague epidemic in London.
desc_long: The Great Plague killed an estimated 100,000 people, about a quarter of London's population.

title: First Cholera Pandemic (1817–1824)
desc: First recorded cholera pandemic, began in India.
desc_long: The first cholera pandemic began in Bengal, spreading through India and Asia, resulting in hundreds of thousands of deaths.

title: Third Cholera Pandemic (1846–1860)
desc: Deadliest cholera pandemic, spread from India to Europe.
desc_long: The third cholera pandemic killed over a million people worldwide, including major outbreaks in London and Russia.

title: Third Plague Pandemic (1855–1960)
desc: The last global outbreak of bubonic plague.
desc_long: Originating in China, the third plague pandemic killed over 12 million people, mainly in India and China.

title: Russian Flu (1889–1890)
desc: A major influenza pandemic originating in Russia.
desc_long: The Russian Flu was an early influenza pandemic that killed about a million people worldwide.

title: Sixth Cholera Pandemic (1899–1923)
desc: Cholera pandemic mainly affecting India and the Middle East.
desc_long: The sixth cholera pandemic killed hundreds of thousands, mostly in India and the Middle East.

title: Spanish Flu (1918–1920)
desc: Deadliest influenza pandemic in history.
desc_long: The 1918 Spanish flu infected one third of the world's population and killed at least 50 million people.

title: Asian Flu (1957–1958)
desc: Global influenza pandemic caused by H2N2 virus.
desc_long: The Asian Flu pandemic caused about 1–2 million deaths worldwide.

title: Hong Kong Flu (1968–1969)
desc: Influenza pandemic caused by H3N2 virus.
desc_long: The Hong Kong Flu infected up to 500 million and killed 1–4 million people worldwide.

title: Ninth Cholera Pandemic (1961–1975)
desc: Most recent cholera pandemic, still ongoing in some regions.
desc_long: The ninth cholera pandemic began in Indonesia and spread worldwide, remaining active in some countries.

title: HIV/AIDS pandemic (1981–present)
desc: Ongoing pandemic of HIV/AIDS.
desc_long: HIV/AIDS has killed over 36 million people worldwide since it was first identified.

title: 2009 H1N1 pandemic (swine flu)
desc: Global outbreak of H1N1 influenza A virus.
desc_long: The 2009 swine flu pandemic was caused by a new strain of H1N1 influenza virus, resulting in an estimated 700 million to 1.4 billion cases worldwide.

title: West African Ebola outbreak (2014–2016)
desc: Deadliest Ebola outbreak in history.
desc_long: The 2014–2016 Ebola outbreak in West Africa was the deadliest occurrence of the disease since its discovery, mainly affecting Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone.

title: COVID-19 pandemic (2020–2023)
desc: Global coronavirus pandemic.
desc_long: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by SARS-CoV-2, spread worldwide beginning in late 2019. It resulted in hundreds of millions of cases and millions of deaths worldwide, leading to widespread social and economic disruption.

title: Great Fire of Rome (AD 64)
desc: Devastating fire in ancient Rome during Emperor Nero's reign.
desc_long: In July AD 64, a large fire destroyed much of the city of Rome, lasting six days and causing widespread devastation. The fire reshaped the city's architecture and politics.

title: Great Fire of London (1212)
desc: Early medieval fire destroyed London Bridge and much of the city.
desc_long: In 1212, a massive fire swept through London, destroying both ends of London Bridge and killing thousands who were trapped by flames.

title: Fire of Moscow (1812)
desc: Fire set during Napoleon's invasion destroyed much of Moscow.
desc_long: During the French invasion, most of Moscow was destroyed by fire—either by retreating Russians or accident—depriving Napoleon's army of shelter.

title: Great Chicago Fire (1871)
desc: Urban fire destroyed large parts of Chicago.
desc_long: From 8–10 October 1871, a fire destroyed thousands of buildings in Chicago, leaving 100,000 people homeless and killing hundreds.

title: Great Boston Fire of 1872
desc: Large urban fire in Boston, Massachusetts.
desc_long: In November 1872, a fire spread through Boston’s downtown, destroying 776 buildings and causing immense economic damage.

title: Peshtigo Fire (1871)
desc: Deadliest wildfire in U.S. history.
desc_long: On 8 October 1871, the Peshtigo Fire swept through Wisconsin, killing between 1,500 and 2,500 people in the deadliest firestorm in American history.

title: Great Thessaloniki Fire (1917)
desc: Urban fire destroyed much of Thessaloniki.
desc_long: In August 1917, a fire devastated Thessaloniki, Greece, leaving 70,000 people homeless and destroying many historic buildings.

title: Hinckley Fire (1894)
desc: Wildfire destroyed Hinckley, Minnesota.
desc_long: On 1 September 1894, a firestorm killed more than 400 people and destroyed several towns in Minnesota.

title: Black Saturday bushfires (2009)
desc: Deadliest bushfires in Australia's history.
desc_long: On 7 February 2009, catastrophic wildfires swept through Victoria, Australia, killing 173 people and destroying thousands of homes.

title: 1988 Yellowstone fires
desc: Extensive wildfires in Yellowstone National Park.
desc_long: During the summer of 1988, wildfires burned nearly 800,000 acres of Yellowstone National Park, changing fire management practices in the U.S.

title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius (AD 79)
desc: Eruption buried Pompeii and Herculaneum.
desc_long: In AD 79, Mount Vesuvius violently erupted, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under ash and pumice.

title: 1755 Lisbon earthquake
desc: One of the deadliest earthquakes and tsunamis in Europe.
desc_long: On 1 November 1755, a massive earthquake struck Lisbon, causing fires and a tsunami that devastated the city and killed tens of thousands.

title: Krakatoa eruption (1883)
desc: Violent volcanic eruption and resulting tsunamis.
desc_long: The eruption of Krakatoa in 1883 destroyed most of the island, triggered huge tsunamis, and caused global climatic effects.

title: 1900 Galveston hurricane
desc: Deadliest natural disaster in U.S. history.
desc_long: In September 1900, a powerful hurricane struck Galveston, Texas, killing 6,000–12,000 people and destroying much of the city.

title: 2008 Sichuan earthquake
desc: Wenchuan earthquake that killed tens of thousands.
desc_long: On 12 May 2008, a magnitude 7.9 earthquake struck Sichuan province, causing nearly 90,000 deaths and widespread destruction.

title: 2010 Haiti earthquake
desc: Catastrophic earthquake near Léogâne, Haiti.
desc_long: On 12 January 2010, a magnitude 7.0 earthquake struck near Port-au-Prince, Haiti, killing over 200,000 people and devastating the capital.

title: 2004 Indian Ocean tsunami
desc: One of the deadliest tsunamis in recorded history.
desc_long: On 26 December 2004, a massive undersea earthquake off Sumatra triggered tsunamis that struck countries around the Indian Ocean, killing over 220,000 people.

title: 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami
desc: Magnitude 9.0 earthquake off Japan causing a devastating tsunami.
desc_long: On 11 March 2011, a massive earthquake and tsunami devastated Japan's Tōhoku region, causing over 15,000 deaths and the Fukushima nuclear disaster.

title: Laki eruption (1783–1784)
desc: One of the deadliest volcanic eruptions in history.
desc_long: The eruption of Laki in Iceland caused widespread famine, killed thousands, and affected climate across the Northern Hemisphere.

title: Deepwater Horizon oil spill (2010)
desc: Massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
desc_long: On 20 April 2010, the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded, causing the largest marine oil spill in history and extensive environmental damage.

title: Chernobyl disaster (1986)
desc: Nuclear accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant.
desc_long: On 26 April 1986, reactor No. 4 at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant exploded during a safety test, releasing large quantities of radioactive contamination into the atmosphere.

title: Bhopal disaster (1984)
desc: Methyl isocyanate gas leak in Bhopal, India.
desc_long: On 2–3 December 1984, a pesticide plant in Bhopal leaked toxic gas, killing thousands and causing chronic health problems for many more.

title: Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster (2011)
desc: Nuclear accident at Fukushima Daiichi after earthquake and tsunami.
desc_long: Following the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami, the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant suffered core meltdowns, hydrogen explosions, and radioactive releases.

title: Three Mile Island accident (1979)
desc: Partial meltdown at a Pennsylvania nuclear plant.
desc_long: On 28 March 1979, a partial core meltdown at Three Mile Island nuclear plant led to the release of radioactive gases in the worst accident in U.S. commercial nuclear power history.

title: Deepwater Horizon oil spill (2010)
desc: Massive oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico.
desc_long: On 20 April 2010, the Deepwater Horizon oil rig exploded, causing the largest marine oil spill in history and extensive environmental damage.

title: Exxon Valdez oil spill (1989)
desc: Major oil spill in Prince William Sound, Alaska.
desc_long: On 24 March 1989, the Exxon Valdez oil tanker struck a reef, spilling over 11 million gallons of crude oil and devastating local ecosystems.

title: Texas City disaster (1947)
desc: Ammonium nitrate explosion in Texas City.
desc_long: On 16 April 1947, a fire aboard a ship carrying ammonium nitrate led to a massive explosion, killing nearly 600 people and destroying much of Texas City.

title: Lac-Mégantic rail disaster (2013)
desc: Runaway train carrying crude oil derailed and exploded.
desc_long: On 6 July 2013, a train carrying crude oil derailed in Lac-Mégantic, Quebec, causing explosions and fires that killed 47 people and destroyed much of the downtown.

title: Granville rail disaster (1977)
desc: Train derailment and bridge collapse in Sydney.
desc_long: On 18 January 1977, a commuter train derailed and struck a bridge, causing it to collapse and kill 83 people in Australia's worst rail disaster.

title: Halifax Explosion (1917)
desc: Maritime explosion devastated Halifax.
desc_long: On 6 December 1917, a collision between two ships in Halifax harbor caused a massive explosion, killing 2,000 people and injuring thousands more.

title: Plague of Cyprian (249–262)
desc: A pandemic that devastated the Roman Empire.
desc_long: The Plague of Cyprian swept through the Roman Empire, causing widespread death and social disruption.

title: Plague of Justinian (541–542)
desc: First recorded outbreak of bubonic plague.
desc_long: The Plague of Justinian was one of the deadliest pandemics, killing millions across the Mediterranean.

title: Black Death (1346–1353)
desc: Devastating global epidemic of bubonic plague.
desc_long: The Black Death killed up to 60% of Europe's population and tens of millions in Asia and Africa.

title: Cocoliztli Epidemics (1545–1576)
desc: Deadly epidemics that struck Mexico after Spanish contact.
desc_long: The Cocoliztli epidemics may have killed 5–15 million indigenous people in Mexico.

title: Smallpox in the Americas (1520–1800)
desc: Smallpox devastated indigenous populations after European contact.
desc_long: Smallpox killed an estimated 56 million people in the Americas, wiping out up to 90% of native populations.

title: Great Plague of London (1665–1666)
desc: Bubonic plague epidemic in London.
desc_long: The Great Plague killed an estimated 100,000 people, about a quarter of London's population.

title: First Cholera Pandemic (1817–1824)
desc: First recorded cholera pandemic, began in India.
desc_long: The first cholera pandemic began in Bengal, spreading through India and Asia.

title: Third Cholera Pandemic (1846–1860)
desc: Deadliest cholera pandemic, spread from India to Europe.
desc_long: The third cholera pandemic killed over a million people worldwide, including major outbreaks in London and Russia.

title: Third Plague Pandemic (1855–1960)
desc: The last global outbreak of bubonic plague.
desc_long: Originating in China, the third plague pandemic killed over 12 million people, mainly in India and China.

title: Russian Flu (1889–1890)
desc: A major influenza pandemic originating in Russia.
desc_long: The Russian Flu was an early influenza pandemic that killed about a million people worldwide.

title: Sixth Cholera Pandemic (1899–1923)
desc: Cholera pandemic mainly affecting India and the Middle East.
desc_long: The sixth cholera pandemic killed hundreds of thousands, mostly in India and the Middle East.

title: Spanish Flu (1918–1920)
desc: Deadliest influenza pandemic in history.
desc_long: The 1918 Spanish flu infected one third of the world's population and killed at least 50 million people.

title: Asian Flu (1957–1958)
desc: Global influenza pandemic caused by H2N2 virus.
desc_long: The Asian Flu pandemic caused about 1–2 million deaths worldwide.

title: Hong Kong Flu (1968–1969)
desc: Influenza pandemic caused by H3N2 virus.
desc_long: The Hong Kong Flu infected up to 500 million and killed 1–4 million people worldwide.

title: Ninth Cholera Pandemic (1961–1975)
desc: Most recent cholera pandemic, still ongoing in some regions.
desc_long: The ninth cholera pandemic began in Indonesia and spread worldwide, remaining active in some countries.

title: HIV/AIDS pandemic (1981–present)
desc: Ongoing pandemic of HIV/AIDS.
desc_long: HIV/AIDS has killed over 36 million people worldwide since it was first identified.

title: 2009 H1N1 pandemic (swine flu)
desc: Global outbreak of H1N1 influenza A virus.
desc_long: The 2009 swine flu pandemic was caused by a new strain of H1N1 influenza virus, resulting in an estimated 700 million to 1.4 billion cases worldwide.

title: West African Ebola outbreak (2014–2016)
desc: Deadliest Ebola outbreak in history.
desc_long: The 2014–2016 Ebola outbreak in West Africa was the deadliest occurrence of the disease since its discovery, mainly affecting Guinea, Liberia, and Sierra Leone.

title: COVID-19 pandemic (2020–2023)
desc: Global coronavirus pandemic.
desc_long: The COVID-19 pandemic, caused by SARS-CoV-2, spread worldwide beginning in late 2019. It resulted in hundreds of millions of cases and millions of deaths worldwide, leading to widespread social and economic disruption.

title: 2022–2023 mpox outbreak
desc: Global outbreak of mpox (monkeypox).
desc_long: The 2022–2023 mpox outbreak saw the spread of monkeypox virus to many non-endemic countries, with thousands of cases reported worldwide.

title: 1755 Lisbon earthquake and tsunami
desc: Catastrophic earthquake and tsunami that hit Lisbon.
desc_long: On 1 November 1755 a massive earthquake struck Lisbon and generated a transatlantic tsunami, devastating the Portuguese capital and coastal communities. The disaster reshaped European thought and early seismology.

title: 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami
desc: Magnitude 9.0 megathrust quake off Japan causing a devastating tsunami.
desc_long: On 11 March 2011 a Mw 9.0 megathrust earthquake struck off the coast of Tōhoku, Japan. The resulting tsunami caused widespread destruction along the Pacific coast and led to the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster.

title: 2004 Indian Ocean earthquake and tsunami
desc: One of the deadliest natural disasters in recorded history.
desc_long: On 26 December 2004 a Mw 9.1–9.3 megathrust earthquake off Sumatra triggered massive tsunamis that struck the coasts of the Indian Ocean, causing more than 220,000 fatalities across 14 countries.

title: Chernobyl disaster (1986)
desc: Nuclear accident at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant.
desc_long: On 26 April 1986 reactor No. 4 at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant exploded during a safety test, releasing large quantities of radioactive contamination into the atmosphere.

title: Great Fire of London (1666)
desc: A major conflagration that swept through central London.
desc_long: From 2–6 September 1666 a major fire consumed large parts of the City of London, destroying thousands of homes and significant landmarks.

title: Beslan school siege (2004)
desc: Hostage crisis at School No. 1 in Beslan.
desc_long: From 1–3 September 2004 more than 1,100 people were taken hostage at School No. 1 in Beslan, North Ossetia. The siege ended in a chaotic battle resulting in over 330 deaths.

title: November 2015 Paris attacks
desc: Coordinated terrorist attacks in Paris.
desc_long: On 13 November 2015 a series of coordinated terrorist attacks occurred in Paris and its northern suburb Saint-Denis, including mass shootings and bombings.

title: Battle of Austerlitz (1805)
desc: Napoleon's decisive victory near Austerlitz.
desc_long: On 2 December 1805 Napoleon defeated the armies of Russia and Austria near Austerlitz, often considered his greatest victory.

title: Battle of Gaugamela (331 BC)
desc: Alexander the Great defeats Darius III.
desc_long: On 1 October 331 BC Alexander the Great decisively defeated the Persian Achaemenid Empire at Gaugamela near modern-day Mosul.

title: Eruption of Mount Vesuvius (AD 79)
desc: Eruption buried Pompeii and Herculaneum.
desc_long: In AD 79 Mount Vesuvius violently erupted, burying the Roman cities of Pompeii and Herculaneum under ash and pumice.

title: Dyatlov Pass incident (1959)
desc: Mysterious deaths of nine hikers in the Urals.
desc_long: In February 1959 nine experienced hikers died under mysterious circumstances in the northern Ural Mountains. The incident has led to numerous theories.

title: Tunguska event (1908)
desc: Large explosion over the Tunguska River region.
desc_long: On 30 June 1908 a large explosion occurred near the Podkamennaya Tunguska River in Siberia, flattening an estimated 80 million trees. The cause is widely believed to have been a meteoroid air burst.

title: Chelyabinsk meteor (2013)
desc: Superbolide over Chelyabinsk Oblast.
desc_long: On 15 February 2013 a superbolide exploded over Chelyabinsk Oblast, injuring around 1,500 people and damaging thousands of buildings.

title: 1906 San Francisco earthquake
desc: Major earthquake that destroyed much of San Francisco.
desc_long: On 18 April 1906 a powerful earthquake and subsequent fires devastated San Francisco and the surrounding area.

title: Portugal Wildfire demo area
desc: Demo wildfire footprint (synthetic).
desc_long: Synthetic example of a wildfire footprint to demonstrate polygon rendering in the app.

title: Rosetta Stone (findspot, 1799)
desc: Granodiorite stele key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs.
desc_long: Discovered in 1799 at Fort Julien (Rashid), the Rosetta Stone provided the key to deciphering Egyptian hieroglyphs because it bears parallel inscriptions in hieroglyphs, Demotic and Ancient Greek.

title: Pompeii archaeological site
desc: World-famous Roman archaeological site.
desc_long: The archaeological site of Pompeii offers unique insights into Roman urban life, preserved under volcanic ash since AD 79.

title: Battle of Stalingrad (1942–43)
desc: Turning point on the Eastern Front in WWII.
desc_long: From August 1942 to February 1943 Axis forces fought the Soviet Red Army for control of Stalingrad (now Volgograd). The battle ended with encirclement and surrender of the German 6th Army.

title: 1980 Irpinia earthquake
desc: Strong earthquake in southern Italy.
desc_long: On 23 November 1980 a magnitude 6.9 earthquake struck the Irpinia region of southern Italy, causing widespread damage and casualties.

title: 1964 Alaska earthquake
desc: The most powerful earthquake recorded in North America.
desc_long: On 27 March 1964 the Mw 9.2 Great Alaska earthquake struck Prince William Sound. Shaking and tsunamis caused extensive damage across Alaska and along the Pacific coast.

title: 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami
desc: Magnitude 9.1 earthquake off the Pacific coast of Tōhoku, causing a devastating tsunami.

title: 1960 Valdivia earthquake
desc: The most powerful earthquake ever recorded (Mw 9.5).

title: 1964 Alaska earthquake
desc: Mw 9.2 earthquake in Prince William Sound, Alaska.

title: 2008 Sichuan earthquake
desc: Wenchuan earthquake that killed tens of thousands.

title: 2015 Nepal earthquake
desc: Gorkha earthquake that struck Nepal on April 25.

title: 2010 Haiti earthquake
desc: Catastrophic earthquake near Léogâne, Haiti.

title: 1976 Tangshan earthquake
desc: Deadly earthquake in Hebei, China.

title: 2003 Bam earthquake
desc: Destructive earthquake in Bam, Iran.

title: 1906 San Francisco earthquake
desc: San Andreas Fault rupture devastated San Francisco.

desc: Atlantic tsunami triggered by the 1755 earthquake.
